awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RUI: how landscape fragmentation interferes with plant-pathogen interactions that maintain local plant diversity
awd_abstract_narration:
Many natural areas are being broken up into smaller fragments due to land-use changes such as suburban sprawl. Compared with larger fragments, small fragments are often extreme environments because they can experience stresses like higher temperatures, more light, and lower soil moisture. This research looks at how plants living in different sized fragments are affected by their pathogens. Interactions between plants and their pathogens are important because although pathogens are best known for the damage they cause they can also help preserve biological diversity. This is because each plant species has its own unique group of pathogens that specialize on it, and slows growth or kills just the plants they infect. This can keep any single plant species from dominating in an area. However, not all pathogens can thrive in the extreme environments found in small patches. It may be that in small patches, different types of pathogens that slow growth or kill multiple plant species indiscriminately are more common. If this is the case, they could decrease plant diversity compared with large patches. By uncovering how plants and pathogens interact in different patch sizes this work will be relevant for understanding the biodiversity consequences of breaking up natural areas, and may affect management of natural landscapes. Both lead researchers for this project are early-career faculty at undergraduate colleges, and will incorporate undergraduate students into all aspects of this work, including community outreach.

Three parallel studies will be conducted to assess how plant-pathogen interactions are altered by landscape fragmentation, focusing on fungal pathogens in particular. First, researchers will bury seeds of twelve plant species in patches of different sizes at the Kansas Fragmentation Site, allowing the seeds to be colonized by potential pathogens and testing to see if the seeds remain viable after a year of burial. This will determine if seed mortality due to fungal pathogens is most influenced by ecological factors that vary with patch size, such as plant host density, plant species richness, and microclimatic conditions (such as temperature and soil moisture). Second, the fungal community from these buried seeds will be characterized using both culture-based methods and culture-independent molecular tools. This will determine whether fungal community structure varies predictably with patch size, host identity, and host density. Finally, a combination of greenhouse and field experiments will test the hypothesis that negative feedbacks (when plants "culture" host-specific pathogens in the soil surrounding their roots) are strongest in the interiors of large patches, rather than on the edges of large patches or in small patches. It is predicted that thermally stressful environments on edges and small patches will favor generalist fungi, reducing the influence of diversity-maintaining feedbacks on smaller fragments. Collectively, these studies link individual plant-fungal interactions to observed landscape patterns in plant diversity.

We explored how landscape fragmentation alters interactions between plants and their fungal pathogens. Fungal pathogens that live in the soil can play an important role in regulating plant population size. In some cases, pathogens can help to maintain plant diversity. Plant species accumulate a specific fungal pathogen community in soil near their roots. These fungi may keep one plant species from dominating the plant community by attacking individual plants of the same species more frequently than other species. In this way, specialized fungal pathogens help each plant species in check, ultimately increasing plant diversity. However, dividing continuous habitats into smaller patches can cause changes in environmental conditions, like temperature and soil moisture, that may disrupt the interactions between plants and their pathogens. We studied the seed stage of the plant life cycle, because seeds can remain in the soil for weeks to years, making them vulnerable to fungal infection. 

We buried seeds of fourteen different plant species (>100,000 seeds total for the full experiment) across a landscape in Lawrence, KS, where patches of different sizes were created on an abandoned agricultural field in 1984. The area between the patches was mowed each year while the vegetation on the patches was left undisturbed, eventually developing into forests. We buried seeds on the edges of large (50 m x 100 m) patches, in the interiors of large patches, within small (4 x 8 m) patches, and in the grassy area between forest patches. We installed a network of sensors that measured soil moisture and temperature at high frequency. After a year underground, seeds were exhumed.

This collaborative project across institutions had several components. Work at Bard College focused on surveying aboveground vegetation in different patch sizes, testing the viability of seeds buried in large vs small patches, and identifying which fungi were pathogenic to seeds of particular plant species. We found that plant species diversity was higher in the largest patches relative to small, and that large and small patches contained distinct plant communities. After isolating fungi from buried seeds, we discovered that the identity of seed-associated fungi differed among host plant species, among patch sizes where seeds were buried, and in response to environmental variables such as soil temperature and moisture.  For a subset of the 250 fungal types we identified, we tested for pathogenicity to demonstrate that fungi found in seeds indeed harmed their seed hosts. We then conducted pathogenicity assays at temperatures similar to environmental conditions characteristic of small and large patches. This series of experiments revealed that the severity of disease, and the number of host species each fungal pathogen type attacked, both depend on temperature. We continue to work with our extensive dataset to identify links between plant community composition, seed viability, severity of disease caused by fungal pathogens, and environmental factors associated with habitat fragmentation.

Along with the scientific goals of this research, this project accomplished several educational and outreach goals. Undergraduate students were instrumental to this work. They collected the majority of the data, and coauthored publications stemming from it. This grant inspired a new course at Bard College, Disease Ecology, focused solely on the research process (a course-based research experience (CRE)). This class provided students access to authentic research experiences their first year of college. Aspects of our research were incorporated into other courses at Bard as well (Plant Ecology, Biostatistics, Symbioses, Biodiversity), and generated multiple year-long senior thesis projects conducted by undergraduates. We also developed several cross-institutional collaborations between classes at Bard College and Sarah Lawrence College, and created opportunities for research students from both campuses to convene each summer. In partnership with the Bard Center for Civic Engagement, Bard students involved in our research project conducted evening outreach activities focused on the hidden diversity of microbial fungi for middle school and elementary students in Red Hook and Kingston. Bard students also created plant- and fungi-related activity videos for kids during the COVID-19 pandemic. Finally, we established a partnership with an elementary school in Kingston. This collaboration allowed Bard students to design and lead educational activities for 2nd graders during multiple visits across a semester, including installing pollinator gardens that have provided the impetus for sustained collaboration.
